instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT is the voltage rail for the backlight of the LCD screen. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.D9701: What is D9701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.

threads.title: [solved] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after liquid damage
threads.message:
The board was liquid damaged 

I wasn't getting voltage at the fuse, replaced <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> and got voltage. Now it appears the circuit is not being boosted to drive the backlight. 
I also replaced 0910


I'm getting 14.3V on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> on the LVDS connector but no backlight. 
I'm guessing there is no boost?
Diode mode measurement on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> is 0.608
SW via is blown?
How do check the SW traces?

threads.title: [solved] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after liquid damage
threads.message: You have teeny tiny kinda sorta boost. What voltage do you get on <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>? If you shove <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> on <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>, do you have backlight? Actually, let's not get ahead here, answer question #1 first before question #2 :)

threads.title: [solved] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after liquid damage
[solved] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after liquid damage
threads.message:
This is odd. <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> 2.7v? 

You check the SW trace by removing the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> and testing continuity of the two switch pads to pin 2 of L9701. It sucks, a waste of an <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>. :( 

but that shouldn't cause this low 14.3v. Is it consistent 14.3v, or is it a spike that then slowly diminishes to 1.2v over time? The latter can mean issue between <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> and L9701 - this is a common path to corrode, and that is what will happen when the via inside the board blows.

Keep the meter there and tell me if it is a consistent 14.3v on backlight output, and also, <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> voltage please! :)

threads.title: [solved] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after liquid damage
threads.message:
3.1V on <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> (measured on <RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR>)

I am now getting 12.53V on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>

threads.title: [solved] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after liquid damage
threads.message:
Removed the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>, I have continuity from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR_SW</SIGNAL> (pin 6 and 7) to pin L9701. 
Does that mean the SW trace is good?

threads.title: [solved] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after liquid damage
threads.message: Yes, trace is ok... check continuity between pin 5 and cathode of <DIODE>D9701</DIODE>...

threads.title: [solved] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after liquid damage
threads.message:
What aprendiz said. Next is feedback missing. 

12.6v means no boosting.No break in the line, but no boosting. 

It would help to see what this looks like.

threads.title: [solved] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after liquid damage
threads.message:
I have continuity between Pin 5 and <DIODE>D9701</DIODE>. 
Is it possible that I did a bad job replacing the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>?

threads.title: [solved] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after liquid damage
threads.message:
I replaced the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> again, and the backlight works!
Thanks for all the help guys

threads.title: [solved] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after liquid damage
threads.message: Push the chip down onto the board hard before applying heat,to make sure it is pressed on all the right pads. If it is floating on one side it won't go on properly. Using flux?

threads.title: [solved] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after liquid damage
threads.message:
Yes, using Amtech 559. I removed the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> yesterday and replaced it and the problem was solved. Backlight now works! I'm waiting on a 4mm nozzle for the my Weller WHA900. Reflow with Chinese air stations sucks! 

Thanks Louis and aprendiz!

threads.title: [solved] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after liquid damage
[solved] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after liquid damage
threads.message:
I'm gonna close this before duke says what he uses as a hot air station and you guys get any ideas. :p ;)

I'm glad this worked!!
